explicatoryContent.introduction: Have you ever thought about who you are online? When you post a photo, write a comment, or share something, you are showing others a part of yourself. This is called your online identity. Your online identity is like a picture of you that others see on the internet. Sometimes this picture is just like the real you. Sometimes it is different. In this topic, we will explore how to be your true self online while staying safe.
keyPoints: Your online identity is who you are on the internet, shown through what you post and share.
What you share online can affect how you feel about yourself.
Other people's posts can make you feel good or bad about yourself.
Being your true self online helps you feel better than pretending to be someone else.
There are simple things you can do to stay safe online.

analogies.analogy: Your online identity is like a scrapbook you make for others to see.
analogies.explanation: Just like you choose what photos and memories to put in a scrapbook, you choose what to share online. Others only see what you put in.

analogies.analogy: Your digital footprint is like footprints in wet cement.
analogies.explanation: Once you step in wet cement, your footprints stay there forever. The same is true for what you post online - it can stay there for a very long time.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Your online identity is made up of everything you do on the internet. This includes your photos, your posts, your comments, and even the pages you follow. All of these things together show others who you are online.

Sometimes people show their true selves online. They post about things they really like and share real thoughts. This is called being authentic. Other times, people only show the best parts of their lives. They might only post photos where they look perfect or only share good news. This can make other people feel bad when they compare themselves.

When we spend time on social media, we see lots of posts from other people. Sometimes seeing these posts makes us happy. Other times, it can make us feel like we are not good enough. This is called social comparison. It is important to remember that most people only show the good parts of their lives online.

Staying safe online is very important. This means being careful about what you share, who you talk to, and what information you give out. You should never share your address, your school name, or other private information with people you do not know.

For Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, identity has always been about connection - to Country, to family, and to community. Online spaces can be places to share and celebrate culture, but it is important to respect what should be shared and what should stay within community.

caseStudy.title: Mia's Two Identities
caseStudy.scenario:
Mia is 13 years old and lives in Perth. She has an Instagram account where she posts photos and stories. Mia notices that she spends a lot of time choosing the perfect photo to post. She takes many photos and only posts the one where she looks best. She also only posts about fun things she does.

At school, Mia feels normal - sometimes happy, sometimes sad, sometimes bored. But when she looks at her Instagram, it looks like she is always happy and always doing exciting things. Her friends' accounts look the same way.

One day, Mia's friend Jasmine tells her she feels sad because everyone else's life looks so perfect on social media. Mia realises she has been feeling the same way. She starts to think about how different her real life is from what she shows online.

She only shares happy and fun moments

Looking at others' posts makes both Mia and Jasmine feel not good enough
questions: Why do you think Mia only posts photos where she looks her best?

caseStudy.realWorldConnection: Many young people feel the same way as Mia and Jasmine. Studies show that what you do on social media matters more than how much time you spend there. Being more authentic and not comparing yourself to others can help you feel better.

explicatoryContent.introduction: Every time you go online, you are creating and sharing parts of your identity. Whether you post a photo, comment on a video, follow an account, or even just like something, you are building your online identity. But here is an important question: Is your online identity the same as who you really are? For many young people, the answer is complicated. In this topic, we will explore how digital spaces shape our sense of self, and how to navigate the online world in ways that support your wellbeing.
keyPoints: Online identity is created through profiles, posts, comments, and interactions in digital spaces.
There is often a gap between how people present themselves online and how they really are.
Social media can both positively and negatively influence how we see ourselves.
Being authentic online means presenting yourself honestly rather than trying to appear perfect.
Digital literacy includes understanding how to stay safe and make wise choices online.

Being genuine and true to who you really are

Controls that let you decide who can see your information and posts online

analogies.analogy: Your online identity is like a highlight reel of a sports game.
analogies.explanation: A highlight reel shows only the best plays and exciting moments, not the whole game with its mistakes and boring parts. Similarly, many people's online profiles show only their best moments, not their whole life.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Your online identity is everything about you that exists in digital spaces. This includes your social media profiles, the photos you post, the comments you make, and even your usernames and the accounts you follow. Together, these create an image of who you are that others can see.

Many people find that their online identity is different from their real-life identity. This is because online, we have control over what we share. We can choose our best photos, share our happiest moments, and hide the parts of ourselves we feel less confident about. This is called curating your online presence.

While there is nothing wrong with wanting to present yourself positively, problems can arise when there is too big a gap between your online self and your real self. Research shows that constantly seeing other people's curated highlights can lead to negative social comparison, where you feel like your life is not as good as everyone else's. This can affect your self-esteem and mental health.

The key is finding a balance. Being authentic online does not mean sharing everything or posting embarrassing moments. It means being honest about who you are and not pretending to be someone you are not. Studies show that people who are more authentic on social media tend to have better wellbeing.

For First Nations Australians, identity is deeply connected to Country, community, and culture. Online spaces can be important places to share and celebrate culture, but it is also important to be respectful of cultural knowledge that should be shared only in certain ways or with certain people. Understanding that different cultures have different approaches to sharing information is part of being a respectful digital citizen.

Staying safe online is also crucial. This means understanding privacy settings, being careful about what personal information you share, and knowing how to respond if something makes you uncomfortable.

caseStudy.title: Tyler's Social Media Reality Check
caseStudy.scenario:
Tyler is 14 and lives in Brisbane. He has accounts on Instagram, TikTok, and Snapchat. Tyler notices that he spends about two hours each day scrolling through social media. He sees posts from influencers with perfect lives and classmates who seem to be having more fun than him.

Lately, Tyler has been feeling down after using social media. He starts to think his life is boring compared to others. He also notices he has been taking more and more photos of himself to get the perfect shot before posting anything. His older sister notices he seems stressed and asks him about it.

Tyler tells his sister that he feels like everyone else has it better than him. His sister points out that she used to feel the same way. She explains that what people post online is usually their best moments, not their everyday reality. She also mentions that some influencers use filters, editing, and even fake scenarios to make their lives look perfect.

He compares his life to what he sees in others' posts

Seeing curated content is affecting his mood and self-esteem
questions: Why do you think Tyler started feeling down after using social media?

caseStudy.realWorldConnection: Research shows that active social media use, like posting and interacting, is often better for wellbeing than passive scrolling. What matters more than time spent online is what you do during that time and how it makes you feel.

strengths: Tyler was able to recognise and talk about how he was feeling
He had a trusted person (his sister) to discuss his concerns with
He was open to hearing a different perspective
improvements: Tyler could set time limits on social media use
He could unfollow accounts that make him feel bad about himself

He could remind himself that posts do not show the full reality

relational.modelResponse: When people post curated content that only shows their best moments, others see these highlights and engage in social comparison, thinking their own lives are not as good. extendedAbstract.stem: Based on what you have learned about online identity and wellbeing, predict how social media might change in the future to better support young people's mental health. What changes would you recommend?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: In the future, social media platforms might include more features that support mental health. They could hide like counts by default to reduce comparison, include prompts asking users if they want a break after scrolling for a while, and provide better tools to manage what content you see. I would recommend that platforms show more realistic content by labelling heavily edited photos, require authenticity warnings on influencer content, and make it easier to connect meaningfully with friends rather than just passively consume content. These changes would help because they address the main problems: comparison, passive scrolling, and unrealistic standards.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Extends learning to make predictions and recommendations based on understanding of current issues

explicatoryContent.introduction: In today's world, your identity does not exist only in face-to-face interactions. A significant part of who you are is expressed, shaped, and perceived through digital platforms. Your online identity includes everything from your Instagram profile to the way you communicate in group chats. But how much does this digital version of yourself reflect the real you? And how does constantly engaging with others' online personas affect how you see yourself? These questions are particularly important during adolescence, when identity development is a central task.
keyPoints: Online identity is a constructed representation of self created through profiles, posts, interactions, and digital choices.
The gap between online presentation and authentic self can create psychological tension and affect wellbeing.
Social comparison on digital platforms is linked to both increased identity exploration and potential identity distress.
Authentic online self-presentation is associated with better self-concept clarity and psychological wellbeing.
Digital safety involves protecting personal information, understanding privacy settings, and recognising harmful interactions.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Online identity refers to the way you present yourself and are perceived in digital spaces. It is constructed through your profiles, the content you post, your interactions with others, and even the choices you make about what to follow or like. This digital self has become an increasingly significant part of overall identity, particularly for young people who have grown up with constant access to social media.

Research shows that online identity and real-life identity are not separate entities but are interconnected parts of the same self. What you do online affects how you see yourself offline, and vice versa. During adolescence, when identity development is a key developmental task, this connection becomes especially important.

One significant phenomenon in digital spaces is social comparison. Studies involving thousands of adolescents have found that what you do on social media matters more than how much time you spend there. Active participation, like posting and interacting, is associated with more identity exploration. However, social comparison is linked to both higher identity exploration and higher identity distress. This means that comparing yourself to others online can prompt thinking about who you are, but it can also cause stress and negative feelings.

Authenticity on social media has been linked to positive outcomes. Research shows that people who present themselves more authentically online tend to have higher self-concept clarity, meaning they have a clearer sense of who they are. The challenge is finding the balance between presenting yourself positively and being genuinely yourself.

For Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, identity is fundamentally connected to Country, community, and culture. Online spaces can provide important opportunities to share, celebrate, and maintain cultural connection. However, there are cultural considerations about what knowledge should be shared publicly and what should remain within communities. Understanding and respecting these cultural protocols is part of being a responsible digital citizen.

Digital safety is also a crucial aspect of online identity. This includes understanding privacy settings, being selective about what personal information you share, recognising and responding to cyberbullying, and knowing where to get help if something goes wrong online.

caseStudy.title: Zara's Digital Balancing Act
caseStudy.scenario:
Zara is a 14-year-old who lives in Melbourne. She is passionate about art and uses Instagram to share her drawings. Over time, she has built a following of other young artists who admire her work. This has been positive for her confidence and has connected her with a community of people who share her interests.

However, Zara has noticed that her social media experience is not all positive. She finds herself spending more time editing her posts to look professional and comparing her work to other artists who seem more talented. She has started to feel anxious about posting because she worries about not getting enough likes. She has also noticed that her feed is full of content that makes her feel inadequate about her appearance, even though she originally followed these accounts for art inspiration.

Zara's older cousin Mei, who is studying psychology at university, visits for the weekend. Zara talks to her about how she has been feeling. Mei explains some research she has learned about: that being authentic online is linked to feeling better about yourself, and that unfollowing accounts that make you feel bad is actually a healthy strategy. She encourages Zara to think about what she wants from her social media experience and to make intentional choices about how she uses it.
observations: Social media has provided genuine benefits for Zara's identity and community
She is experiencing negative effects from comparison and performance pressure
The content she sees has expanded beyond her original interests
She has access to a supportive person who can offer perspective and strategies
questions: How has social media both positively and negatively affected Zara's identity development?
What strategies could Zara use to maintain the benefits while reducing the negative effects?
How might Zara's experience be different from someone who uses social media primarily for passive scrolling?
caseStudy.realWorldConnection: Research shows that social media is not inherently good or bad for identity development. What matters is how you use it. Active, authentic engagement tends to have better outcomes than passive consumption and comparison. The key is being intentional about your digital choices.

strengths: Zara has found a community that supports her interests and identity
She is self-aware enough to recognise when social media is affecting her negatively
She has trusted people she can talk to about her experiences
improvements: Zara could audit her feed and unfollow accounts that do not serve her wellbeing
She could set boundaries around when and how she checks for engagement on posts
She could remind herself that her value as an artist is not determined by likes
She could focus on the process of creating art rather than external validation

explicatoryContent.introduction: In the contemporary landscape, digital spaces have become integral arenas for identity work. The profiles we craft, the content we share, and the personas we project online are not merely reflections of who we arethey actively participate in shaping who we become. This reciprocal relationship between digital self-presentation and identity development presents both opportunities and challenges, particularly during adolescence when identity formation is a central developmental task. Understanding the psychological mechanisms at play enables more intentional navigation of these digital environments.
keyPoints: Online identity operates as both a product of self-expression and a force that shapes subsequent identity development through feedback loops.
Social comparison processes on digital platforms can simultaneously promote identity exploration and precipitate identity distress.
Authenticity in digital self-presentation correlates with enhanced self-concept clarity and psychological wellbeing.
The distinction between active engagement and passive consumption significantly influences digital identity outcomes.
Cultural contexts, including Indigenous perspectives on relational identity, provide important frameworks for understanding digital self-presentation.

vocabulary.definition: The complex of self-representations, persona constructions, and relational presentations maintained across digital platforms
The degree to which an individual's beliefs about their own attributes are clearly defined, internally consistent, and stable
Identity understood as something enacted and constructed through social performances rather than as a fixed essence
A psychological framework explaining how individuals evaluate their own abilities and opinions by comparing themselves to others
The conscious or unconscious process of regulating information to influence others' perceptions

analogies.analogy: Online identity construction is similar to method actingyou become what you repeatedly perform.
analogies.explanation: Just as actors who deeply embody characters can find their own sense of self influenced by those roles, the personas we consistently project online can influence our actual self-concept over time.

analogies.analogy: Social media feeds function like distorted mirrors in a funhouse.
analogies.explanation: What we see reflected back is not reality but a warped version that can make us feel inadequate when we compare our full selves to others' curated highlights. Understanding this distortion is crucial for maintaining perspective.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Digital identity represents a multifaceted phenomenon that extends beyond simple online profiles. It encompasses the totality of one's presence across digital platformsthe content created and shared, the interactions engaged in, the communities joined, and even the patterns of consumption and engagement. This digital self exists in a dynamic relationship with broader identity development.

Research examining social media and adolescent identity development reveals a nuanced picture. A systematic review of 32 studies with nearly 20,000 participants found that what adolescents do on social media matters more than the time they spend there. Active participation, as opposed to passive consumption, is associated with increased identity exploration. However, social comparison processesevaluating oneself against the curated presentations of otherscorrelate with both heightened identity exploration and increased identity distress.

The concept of authenticity proves central to understanding healthy digital identity. Studies indicate that authentic self-presentation online correlates with higher self-concept claritya clear, stable understanding of who you are. Conversely, significant discrepancies between one's online persona and actual self can create psychological tension and undermine wellbeing. This does not mean that all self-curation is problematic; rather, the key is maintaining fundamental consistency between digital presentation and genuine self.

Age emerges as a significant moderating factor in these relationships. Research suggests that younger adolescents (10-15 years) may be more vulnerable to negative effects of social media on identity than older adolescents (16-19 years) who have developed more stable identity foundations. This developmental perspective underscores the importance of building digital literacy skills early.

Cultural contexts significantly shape how digital identity is understood and enacted. For Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, identity is fundamentally relational and connected to Country, community, and cultural knowledge. Digital spaces can serve as important venues for cultural expression and connection, but they also raise questions about appropriate sharing of cultural knowledge. Understanding that different cultural frameworks approach identity and self-presentation differently is essential for navigating diverse digital environments.

Digital citizenship extends beyond personal wellbeing to encompass ethical considerations about how our online presence affects others. The concept of digital footprintthe permanent trail of online activityhighlights the long-term implications of digital choices. Developing critical awareness of these dynamics supports more intentional and healthy engagement with digital spaces.

caseStudy.title: Kai's Intersecting Digital Worlds
caseStudy.scenario:
Kai is a 15-year-old of Japanese-Australian heritage living in Sydney. They maintain different online presences across platforms: an Instagram account where they share photography with school friends, a Discord server where they connect with an international anime community, and a private TikTok where they experiment with content without public scrutiny.

Kai finds that each space allows them to explore different aspects of their identity. On Instagram, they present a curated image that aligns with their school social group. On Discord, they engage more deeply with cultural interests they feel might be seen as 'nerdy' at school. On TikTok, they experiment with creative expression without worrying about judgment.

Recently, Kai has been reflecting on how these different digital selves relate to each other and to their 'true' self. They sometimes feel like they are being authentic on all platforms, just showing different facets of themselves. Other times, they worry that maintaining different personas is somehow inauthentic or fragmented.

Kai's grandmother, who grew up in Japan, shares her perspective that identity in Japanese culture is traditionally understood as contextualone naturally presents differently in different social contexts. She suggests that having multiple digital selves might not be fragmenting but rather reflects the natural complexity of human identity.
observations: Kai uses different platforms for different identity expressions
Each platform serves distinct social and psychological functions
They experience tension between unity and multiplicity in self-presentation
Cultural perspectives from their grandmother offer an alternative framework for understanding

caseStudy.realWorldConnection: Research increasingly recognises that identity is context-dependent and that presenting different aspects of self in different settings is normal and healthy. The key consideration is whether these different presentations share core values and represent genuine facets of self, rather than fundamental deception or identity confusion.

relational.stem: Explain how the interplay between authenticity, social comparison, and self-concept clarity operates in digital environments to influence adolescent wellbeing.
relational.modelResponse: These three concepts form an interconnected system. Authenticity in digital self-presentation supports self-concept clarity by reducing cognitive dissonance between presented and actual self. However, social comparison can undermine authenticity by creating pressure to present an idealised image. When people sacrifice authenticity due to comparison pressure, self-concept clarity suffers because the gap between online and real self creates confusion. Conversely, when someone maintains authenticity despite comparison pressure, their self-concept clarity is reinforced. This suggests that authenticity may serve as a protective factor mediating the relationship between social comparison and wellbeing.

extendedAbstract.stem: Drawing on concepts from this topic and your broader understanding of identity development, theorise how digital identity formation might need to be reconceptualised as digital environments become increasingly immersive (e.g., virtual reality, augmented reality, AI companions).

In VR environments where embodiment feels real, identity might be formed through genuinely lived experiences rather than curated presentations. This could mean that concepts like 'authenticity' need reconceptualisationif VR experiences feel real, are they less authentic than physical experiences? AI companions might create new attachment relationships that influence identity development, potentially offering both opportunities (safe spaces for exploration) and risks (substituting for human connection). Erikson's concept of psychosocial moratorium might extend into these new spaces, with virtual worlds offering identity experimentation without real-world consequences. However, this raises questions about transferdo identities developed in virtual spaces translate to other contexts? Future frameworks may need to move beyond the real/digital binary toward understanding identity across a continuum of embodied and mediated experiences.

explicatoryContent.introduction: The emergence of pervasive digital environments has necessitated a fundamental reconsideration of identity formation processes. Digital identity represents not merely an extension of traditional identity work into new media, but potentially a qualitatively distinct phenomenon that challenges established theoretical frameworks. The simultaneity of identity construction and performance, the persistence of digital traces, and the unprecedented scale of social comparison opportunities create conditions for identity development that previous generations did not experience. Understanding these dynamics requires interdisciplinary analysis drawing on developmental psychology, media studies, sociology, and cultural theory.
keyPoints: Digital identity construction operates through performative processes where presentation and formation are mutually constitutive.
Empirical research reveals complex, non-linear relationships between social media engagement and identity outcomes, moderated by behavioural patterns and developmental stage.
The concept of authenticity requires critical examination when applied to digital contexts, as Western individualistic assumptions may not translate across cultural frameworks.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander conceptualisations of relational identity and community knowledge protocols offer alternative paradigms for understanding appropriate digital self-presentation.
Digital literacy encompasses not only technical competencies but also critical awareness of the psychological and social dynamics embedded in digital environments.

vocabulary.definition: Drawing on Judith Butler's work, the concept that identity is not an inherent essence but is continuously constructed through repeated social performances
A psychological construct measuring the extent to which self-beliefs are clearly defined, internally consistent, and temporally stable
Comparing oneself to individuals perceived as superior on relevant dimensions, which can motivate improvement or undermine self-evaluation
From Goffman's dramaturgical theory, the process of attempting to influence others' perceptions through strategic self-presentation
The study of how digital environments are experienced and how they shape human consciousness and self-understanding
The social arrangement where individuals rather than households or groups are the primary unit of connectivity
The guidelines and rules within a culture that govern appropriate behaviour, including what knowledge can be shared and with whom
Erikson's concept of a sanctioned period during which adolescents can experiment with identities without permanent consequences

analogies.analogy: Digital identity formation resembles a palimpsesta manuscript that has been written on, erased, and written on again, with traces of earlier versions remaining visible beneath the current text.
analogies.explanation: Like a palimpsest, our digital identities bear the traces of previous self-presentations even as we write new versions. The persistence of digital information means earlier identity expressions remain potentially visible, creating a layered record of identity development.

analogies.analogy: The relationship between digital self and embodied self is analogous to the relationship between a musical score and its performance.
analogies.explanation: A score provides a framework that shapes performance, but each performance also interprets and potentially transforms the score. Similarly, our digital presentations shape subsequent embodied identity, while our lived experience influences how we present digitallyneither has priority as the 'authentic' version.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Digital identity represents a complex nexus where theoretical frameworks from multiple disciplines converge. From a developmental psychology perspective, digital environments have become significant contexts for the identity work that Erikson identified as central to adolescence. The concept of psychosocial moratoriuma sanctioned period for identity experimentationfinds new expression in digital spaces where young people can try out different self-presentations with potentially lower stakes than face-to-face contexts.

However, the permanence of the digital footprint complicates this moratorium. Unlike face-to-face interactions where awkward moments may be forgotten, digital traces persist and can resurface. This creates a paradox: digital spaces offer unprecedented opportunities for identity experimentation, yet they also create permanent records that may constrain future identity options.

Empirical research on digital identity and wellbeing reveals nuanced findings that resist simple conclusions. A systematic review examining 32 studies with 19,658 participants found that engagement patterns, rather than mere exposure, predict outcomes. Active participation is associated with increased identity exploration, while social comparison correlates with both heightened exploration and increased distress. Significantly, age moderates these relationshipsyounger adolescents (10-15) appear more vulnerable to negative effects than older adolescents (16-19) who have more established identity foundations.

The concept of authenticity in digital contexts requires critical examination. Research indicates that authentic self-presentation online correlates with self-concept clarity and wellbeing. However, the Western conceptualisation of authenticity as fidelity to an inner, individual self does not translate straightforwardly across cultural contexts.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander perspectives offer an important alternative framework. In many First Nations conceptualisations, identity is fundamentally relationaldefined through connections to Country, community, kinship, and ancestral knowledge rather than individual attributes. This relational ontology has significant implications for understanding appropriate digital self-presentation. Cultural protocols govern what knowledge can be shared and with whom; some knowledge belongs to particular communities, genders, or ceremonies and should not be broadcast publicly. Understanding these protocols is essential for respectful engagement in digital spaces.

Goffman's dramaturgical framework provides analytical tools for examining digital self-presentation as a form of impression management. In this view, all social interaction involves performance, and digital environments simply make certain aspects of performance more visible and controllable. The question becomes not whether to engage in impression managementwhich is ubiquitousbut how to manage impressions in ways that maintain integrity between presented and experienced self.

Synthesising these perspectives suggests that healthy digital identity requires: critical awareness of the psychological dynamics at play, intentionality about self-presentation choices, maintenance of reasonable coherence between digital and embodied selves, cultural competence regarding diverse approaches to identity and sharing, and practical digital literacy skills for managing privacy and safety.

caseStudy.title: Amara's Cross-Cultural Digital Navigation
caseStudy.scenario:
Amara is a 16-year-old whose family is Sudanese-Australian. She was born in Australia but maintains strong connections to her family's cultural heritage. Amara has been reflecting on how her digital presence intersects with questions of cultural identity and authentic self-presentation.

On TikTok, Amara creates content that draws on Sudanese cultural traditions, including traditional music and cuisine. This content has attracted a substantial following, and Amara enjoys how it connects her with other Sudanese diaspora youth. However, she has begun to feel tension around what to share. Her grandmother has expressed concern that some family traditions are being shared too publicly. Meanwhile, her Australian school friends sometimes seem to exoticise or stereotype her cultural content.

In an academic context, Amara has been studying Goffman's concept of impression management and Butler's theory of performative identity. She finds herself applying these frameworks to her own experience. She wonders: Is her cultural content authentic self-expression or a curated performance of ethnicity for an audience? Is there a meaningful difference? How should she navigate between her grandmother's traditional views on cultural knowledge sharing and contemporary digital culture where sharing is normalised?

Amara's uncle, who is a community elder, offers a perspective that traditional knowledge was always shared contextuallydifferent information for different audiencesand that her grandmother's concern is not about sharing per se but about maintaining appropriate contexts. This gives Amara a new framework for thinking about her digital presence: perhaps the question is not whether to share but how to create appropriate digital contexts for different kinds of content.
observations: Amara is engaging with complex intersections of cultural and digital identity
She experiences multiple, potentially conflicting audiences for her content
Academic frameworks provide analytical tools she can apply to lived experience
Cultural perspectives offer alternative frameworks for understanding appropriate sharing
questions: How might Goffman's concept of front-stage and back-stage regions apply to Amara's navigation of different digital audiences?
In what ways does the concept of cultural protocols challenge Western assumptions about digital authenticity?
How might Amara's uncle's perspective on contextual sharing provide a framework for ethical digital self-presentation?
caseStudy.realWorldConnection: Many young people from diverse cultural backgrounds navigate similar tensions between traditional knowledge protocols and digital sharing norms. Understanding that concepts like 'authenticity' are culturally constructed allows for more sophisticated navigation of these challenges.

She seeks multiple perspectives, including intergenerational and academic views
She is willing to apply theoretical frameworks to her lived experience

improvements: Amara could develop more explicit frameworks for what content belongs in which contexts
She could communicate more directly with her grandmother about her concerns and intentions

remember.stem: According to Erikson's developmental framework, what concept describes the sanctioned period during adolescence for identity experimentation?

options.text: Identity achievement
options.feedback: Not quite. Identity achievement is the outcome of successful identity development, not the period of experimentation. The period of experimentation is called psychosocial moratorium.

options.text: Psychosocial moratorium
options.feedback: Correct. Psychosocial moratorium refers to the culturally sanctioned period allowing adolescents to experiment with different identities without permanent consequences.

options.text: Role confusion
options.feedback: Not quite. Role confusion is the negative outcome when identity development is unsuccessful. The period of experimentation is psychosocial moratorium.

options.text: Identity diffusion
options.feedback: Not quite. Identity diffusion is one of Marcia's identity statuses characterised by neither exploration nor commitment. Erikson's term for the experimentation period is psychosocial moratorium.

remember.stem: What key finding emerged from systematic review research on adolescent social media use and identity?

options.text: Total time on social media is the strongest predictor of identity outcomes
options.feedback: Not quite. Research found that time spent is less predictive than behaviour patterns. What adolescents do on social media matters more than how long they spend there.

options.text: All social media use negatively impacts adolescent identity development
options.feedback: Not quite. Research reveals a more nuanced picture, with some types of engagement (like active participation) associated with positive outcomes including increased identity exploration.

options.text: Behavioural patterns and type of engagement matter more than time spent on platforms
options.feedback: Correct. Systematic review research found that what adolescents do on social media is more predictive of identity outcomes than how much time they spend online.

options.text: Older adolescents are more vulnerable to negative effects than younger adolescents
options.feedback: Not quite. Research suggests the opposite: younger adolescents (10-15) appear more vulnerable to negative effects than older adolescents (16-19) who have more established identity foundations.

unistructural.stem: Identify ONE way that digital environments have changed the conditions for adolescent identity development compared to previous generations.
unistructural.modelResponse: One significant change is the persistence of digital traces, meaning that identity experiments and expressions that would have been ephemeral in face-to-face contexts now create permanent records.
unistructural.rubric: Identifies one substantive change in conditions

multistructural.stem: List FIVE theoretical concepts from different disciplines that can be applied to understanding digital identity.
multistructural.modelResponse: Five concepts are: psychosocial moratorium from Erikson's developmental psychology, impression management from Goffman's sociology, performative identity from Butler's cultural theory, social comparison from social psychology, and relational identity from Indigenous studies.
multistructural.rubric: Lists five relevant concepts from different disciplines

relational.stem: Explain how the concepts of performative identity, digital persistence, and psychosocial moratorium interact to create unique conditions for contemporary adolescent identity development.
relational.modelResponse: These three concepts interact in complex ways. Performative identity theory suggests that identity is continuously constructed through social performances rather than being a fixed essence. Digital environments amplify this by making performances more visible, controllable, and shareable. However, digital persistence creates a paradox: while Erikson's psychosocial moratorium assumes that adolescent identity experiments can occur without permanent consequences, digital traces mean that earlier performances remain accessible, potentially constraining future identity options. This creates a unique developmental context where identity is understood as performative and experimental (moratorium) but where those experiments are recorded (persistence). Young people must navigate this by being more intentional about which performances to record and how to contextualise past digital selves.
relational.rubric: Shows integrated understanding of how all three concepts interact

extendedAbstract.stem: Drawing on concepts from developmental psychology, cultural theory, and Indigenous knowledge systems, theorise how the concept of 'authentic digital identity' might need to be reconceptualised for a pluralistic, post-colonial context.
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Reconceptualising authentic digital identity for a pluralistic context requires moving beyond Western individualistic assumptions. Current authenticity frameworks assume a core inner self that should be expressed consistentlybut this is culturally specific. A post-colonial reconceptualisation might draw on Indigenous relational ontologies where identity is constituted through connections rather than contained within individuals. Authentic digital identity would then be about maintaining appropriate relationships and responsibilities across contexts rather than expressing a singular inner self. This allows for contextual self-presentation (different content for different relationships) without accusations of inauthenticity. From cultural theory, we might incorporate Butler's insight that all identity is performative, dissolving the authentic/inauthentic binary. Authentic would no longer mean 'true to inner self' but perhaps 'ethically engaged in relationship.' This framework would evaluate digital identity practices not by correspondence to an inner essence but by their relational consequences: Do they maintain appropriate connections? Do they respect cultural protocols? Do they contribute to community wellbeing? Such a framework would be more applicable across diverse cultural contexts while still providing ethical guidance for digital self-presentation.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Synthesises multiple theoretical traditions to produce novel reconceptualisation

What tensions do you experience between different cultural frameworks for understanding authenticity in your own digital life?
How might your understanding of digital identity inform advocacy for more ethical digital environments?
